posts.post_content:
A reprint I've been waiting for. Not exactly a fan of the new art although it's at least more appropriate for a horror set than Rebecca Guay's version.  
  
Looks fun but really needs to use the milled cards (or combo with some way of ensuring the land's on top of your deck) to be effective. 2 mana for 1-2 land on average with no ramp just isn't worth it when it's unreliable.  
  
Now when the milled cards are powering up lhurgoyfs, being cast via flashback and returning to the battlefield...

posts.post_content:
(Removed from the old version of Mulch and placed here for relevancy's sake. Man do I miss that Rebecca Guay art though.)  
  
[Mulch](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mulch), despite the rap it gets, really isn't a double-edged sword, statistically speaking (with some fringe exceptions... more on that later\*).  
  
It's true that sometimes you really want to see card X (or more likely, card X or card Y or card Z), and Mulch forces you to discard it. Well, that sucks. But played out over enough games, you'll be just as likely for Mulch to get card X/Y/Z out faster as you are to have it take longer. It doesn't always *seem* that way, because it's a lot easier to notice when Mulch discards the card you needed than it is to notice that Mulch got you four cards closer to the card you needed. Average out how much it's slowed you down by passing a key card vs. how many times it's gotten you one sooner, and it will almost always come out to 50/50 or thereabouts. (Same is true for being milled, but that doesn't... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

But played out over enough games, you'll be just as likely for Mulch to get card X/Y/Z out faster as you are to have it take longer. It doesn't always seem that way, because it's a lot easier to notice when Mulch discards the card you needed than it is to notice that Mulch got you four cards closer to the card you needed. posts.post_content: Great card. Not only will it fetch you land, but it will place what it can't fetch into your graveyard. And in Innistrad, having things in the graveyard is good, because you can tutor for stuff in there with all the graveyard focused abilities in the set.

posts.post_content:
This is easy. ![Black or Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=BG&type=symbol) Zombies.  
  
Turn 2 - Mulch (Grab say, 2 land)  
Turn 3 - [Ghoulcaller's Chant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ghoulcaller's Chant), pulling the two non-lands back to your hand.  
- OR -  
Turn 3 - [Unbreathing Horde](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Unbreathing Horde), for 3 counters (provided you dropped [Diregraf Ghoul](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Diregraf Ghoul) on T1)  
  
Sure, it isn't constructed worthy, but in a deck that likes it's spells in the graveyard as much as it's hand, this looks a lot nicer late game than top decking a [Rampant Growth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rampant Growth).  
  
@luca\_barelli  
I don't see it. Yeah, the end results might be similar sometimes (a lot of land in hand) but functionally, they are two entirely different animals. For one, Treasure Hunt gives you a non-land card in hand.
